title: 108_hr1079
content: The "Neutral Cost Recovery Act for Small Business" may be cited as the Short Title. It includes Increased Expensing for Small Business. The "Neutral Cost Recovery Act for Small Business" includes amendments to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. It increases the dollar limitation for aggregate costs under section 179(b) to $75,000 and raises the phaseout threshold to $325,000. Additionally, it defines "section 179 property" to include tangible property as specified in section 168. The term 'section 179 property' includes tangible property, computer software, and section 1245 property acquired for use in a trade or business. It excludes certain types of property and air conditioning or heating units. Subsection (b) of section 179 is amended to include inflation adjustments for taxable years. Inflation adjustments are made to the dollar limitation and phaseout threshold for taxable years beginning after 2003. The dollar amounts in paragraphs (1) and (2) are increased based on the cost-of-living adjustment for the calendar year. If the increased amount is not a multiple of $1,000, it is rounded to the nearest multiple. The amendment to section 179(c) of the Code allows taxpayers to revoke an election under paragraph (1) with respect to any property, making it irrevocable once done. These changes apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 2002. SEC. 3. NEUTRAL COST RECOVERY DEPRECIATION ADJUSTMENT FOR CERTAIN PROPERTY PLACED IN SERVICE AFTER DECEMBER 31, 2003. Section 168 of the Internal Revenue Code is amended to allow for a deduction adjustment to mimic expensing for certain property placed in service after December 31, 2003. The deduction amount is modified to 150 percent instead of 200 percent for property eligible for full expensing under section 179. The applicable neutral cost recovery ratio for property placed in service is determined by dividing the gross domestic product deflator for the corresponding calendar quarter by the gross domestic product. The applicable neutral cost recovery ratio for property placed in service is calculated by multiplying a number by 1.035 to the nth power, where 'n' is the number of full years from the quarter the property was placed in service. The ratio should never be less than 1. The applicable neutral cost recovery ratio for property placed in service is calculated based on the number of full years from the quarter the property was placed in service. The ratio should never be less than 1 and is rounded to the nearest \1/1000\. There is a special rule for certain types of property, and taxpayers can elect not to have this subsection apply to their property. The subsection provides rules for electing not to apply certain provisions to property, including churning transactions and additional deductions that do not affect the property's basis or recapture. The curr_chunk discusses the minimum tax treatment for certain types of entities, including pass-thru entities like regulated investment companies, real estate investment trusts, S corporations, partnerships, estates, trusts, and common trust funds. It also mentions the use of a neutral cost recovery ratio for property placed in service after December 31, 2003. The text discusses the neutral cost recovery deduction for property placed in service after December 31, 2003, and its coordination with depreciation limitations on certain entities. The amendment applies to the coordination of depreciation limitations on passenger automobiles, with the effective date for taxable years ending after December 31, 2003.
